Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: A New Bio-based Monomer for the Coatings Industry
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project lies in the replacement of key petroleum-based chemicals used in the paints and coatings industry, representing a $7B industry that is growing at 7% per year. The total addressable market includes 3 similar diols: 1,4-butanediol (1,4-BDO), 1,5-pentanediol (1,5-PDO), and 1,6-hexanediol (1,6-HDO). In this project, 1,5-PDO is produced from furfural, a chemical made from renewable agricultural residues such as corn cobs and wood chips. Bio-based 1,5-PDO can be readily substituted for 1,6-HDO in many applications due to its analogous molecular structure and is similar enough to 1,4-BDO that it can be substituted for it in some applications. Rigorous technoeconomic analysis shows that this "green" 1,5-PDO can be made at 3x lower costs than oil-derived 1,5-PDO, opening new opportunities for its use as a renewable monomer for paints, coatings, adhesives and plastics.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase 1 project will allow the technology to be developed with commercially available fixed bed pellet catalysts to prepare the technology for scale-up. Thus far, the technology has been demonstrated in small scale fixed bed reactors with powder catalysts. A commercial scale process requires the use of pelletized catalysts due to inoperable pressure drops over powder catalysts in commercial-scale reactors. The higher flowrates inherent with larger scale reactors cannot flow through the tightly packed powder catalysts and cause a large degree of backpressure upstream of the catalyst bed; thus, pelletized catalysts must be sourced from commercial vendors and tested for activity and stability prior to scaling. The next phase in technology development is to scale up the process by >100x, enabling testing and validation of larger amounts of the bio-based 1,5-PDO product in potential customers' product lines. This SBIR Phase I project will also allow completion of the process design work needed to estimate the economics at commercial scale.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Pyran is developing our patented chemical reaction technology to produce low-cost, renewable 1,5-pentanediol (1,5-PDO), a key chemical used to manufacture paints, coatings, adhesives, and plastics. 1,5-PDO belongs to a class of chemicals called “diols” which are used as monomers in various industrial applications, essentially acting as puzzle pieces used to put together larger molecular structures. Currently, these diols are manufactured from oil (petroleum), using complex, expensive, and hazardous processes. Pyran’s renewable 1,5-PDO is expected to be able to quickly replace two oil-based diols – 1,5-PDO and 1,6-hexanediol (1,6-HDO) – across a wide variety of applications and market segments (Fig. 1). Detailed economic and market analyses have indicated that Pyran’s 1,5-PDO can be sold for 25-50% lower costs compared to oil-based 1,5-PDO and 1,6-HDO.

Pyran uncovered and improved upon a novel 4-step chemical pathway to produce 1,5-PDO (Fig. 2). Pyran’s 1,5-PDO is made from furfural, a chemical derived from renewable biomass sources such as corn cobs, wood wastes, and other agricultural residues. No commercial process currently exists that converts furfural into 1,5-PDO. By using a biomass feedstock, Pyran’s approach is lower-cost and has a smaller carbon footprint compared to current commercial methods of producing diols. The promotion of Pyran’s 1,5-PDO production would also create market demand for domestic furfural production, thus providing new markets to use agricultural wastes. Bio-based chemicals can decrease the nation’s dependence on petroleum and reduce greenhouse gas emmisions while creating value and jobs for the U.S. economy.

The main goal of this NSF SBIR Phase I project was to further develop our technology by obtaining and characterizing commercially available pelletized catalysts for each of our reaction steps requiring catalysts (1, 2, & 4). Catalysts are materials that substantially increase the rate of a chemical reaction. Catalysts are widely used in the chemical industry to increase the productivity (rates) of chemical reactions to improve their economic potential. In research preceding our NSF Phase I effort, a variety of catalysts were tested in powder form for each reaction step in our process. However, commercial scale processes require the use of pelletized catalysts. This is because larger reactors use higher liquid and gas flowrates, which would produce very large pressure drops over densely packed powder catalysts. In practice, there are many risks associated with scaling up a chemical process and switching to larger reactors with pelletized catalysts. These risks stem from the unforeseen effects of new conditions on the desired chemical reactions in the process. It is desired to derisk the scale-up process as much as possible by collecting data at the laboratory scale using commercial catalysts and conditions relevent to manufacturing-scale production prior to designing larger reactors.

Under this Phase I project, Pyran was able to successfully source, obtain, and characterize commercial pelletized catalysts for each reaction. These catalysts met a majority of our Phase I performance milestones and produced a technically and economically feasible process in our commercial scale economic model. The highest performing catalysts were downselected for further studies, where they were tested under various conditions representative of commercial operation. Data obtained in these experiments were used to build a preliminary reactor model that will allow Pyran to predict the behavior of our commercial catalysts in larger scale reactors. The findings of this project will help Pyran design larger reactors and derisk our process during scale-up as we move towards commercialization.

 

 


 


Last Modified: 03/11/2020
Modified by: Kevin J Barnett

Images (1 of )
  • Major market uses for 1,5-pentanediol (1,5-PDO) and 1,6-hexanediol (1,6-HDO). These diols are combined with a comonomer to produce a variety of prepolymer materials (polyesters, polycarbonates, etc.). These prepolymers are further upgraded to paints, plastics, coatings, and adhesives.
    Pyran, LLC
    Kevin J Barnett
    Figure 1: Market Uses for 1,5-PDO and 1,6-HDO
  • Pyran's patented process to make 1,5-pentanediol (1,5-PDO) from biomass derived furfural. The process requires 4 reaction steps. Steps 1, 2, & 4 require catalysts, and were the subjects of this project.
    Pyran, LLC
    Copyrighted
    Kevin J Barnett
    Figure 2: Pyran's patented process
